column2: Ruin the work of a lifetime, I heard Moreau say.
column3: Ruin the work of a lifetime, I heard Moreau say.

column2: He does not understand, said Montgomery. and other things that were inaudible.
column3: He does not understand, said Montgomery. and other things that were inaudible.

column2: I can't spare the time yet, said Moreau.
column3: I can't spare the time yet, said Moreau.

column2: The rest I did not hear.
column3: The rest I did not hear.

column2: I picked myself up and stood trembling, my mind a chaos of the most horrible misgivings.
column3: I picked myself up and stood trembling, my mind a chaos of the most horrible misgivings.

column2: Could it be possible, I thought, that such a thing as the vivisection of men was carried on here?
column3: Could it be possible, I thought, that such a thing as the vivisection of men was carried on here?

column2: The question shot like lightning across a tumultuous sky; and suddenly the clouded horror of my mind condensed into a vivid realisation of my own danger.
column3: The question shot like lightning across a tumultuous sky; and suddenly the clouded horror of my mind condensed into a vivid realisation of my own danger.

column2: XI.
column3: XI.

column2: THE HUNTING OF THE MAN.
column3: THE HUNTING OF THE MAN.

column2: IT came before my mind with an unreasonable hope of escape that the outer door of my room was still open to me.
column3: i t came before my mind with an unreasonable hope of escape that the outer door of my room was still open to me.

column2: I was convinced now, absolutely assured, that Moreau had been vivisecting a human being. All the time since I had heard his name, I had been trying to link in my mind in some way the grotesque animalism of the islanders with his abominations; and now I thought I saw it all. The memory of his work on the transfusion of blood recurred to me. These creatures I had seen were the victims of some hideous experiment. These sickening scoundrels had merely intended to keep me back, to fool me with their display of confidence, and presently to fall upon me with a fate more horrible than death,--with torture; and after torture the most hideous degradation it is possible to conceive,--to send me off a lost soul, a beast, to the rest of their Comus rout.
column3: I was convinced now, absolutely assured, that Moreau had been vivisecting a human being. All the time since I had heard his name, I had been trying to link in my mind in some way the grotesque animalism of the islanders with his abominations; and now I thought I saw it all. The memory of his work on the transfusion of blood recurred to me. These creatures I had seen were the victims of some hideous experiment. These sickening scoundrels had merely intended to keep me back, to fool me with their display of confidence, and presently to fall upon me with a fate more horrible than death,--with torture; and after torture the most hideous degradation it is possible to conceive,--to send me off a lost soul, a beast, to the rest of their Comus rout.

column2: I looked round for some weapon.
column3: I looked round for some weapon.

column2: Nothing.
column3: Nothing.

column2: Then with an inspiration I turned over the deck chair, put my foot on the side of it, and tore away the side rail.
column3: Then with an inspiration I turned over the deck chair, put my foot on the side of it, and tore away the side rail.

column2: It happened that a nail came away with the wood, and projecting, gave a touch of danger to an otherwise petty weapon. I heard a step outside, and incontinently flung open the door and found Montgomery within a yard of it.
column3: It happened that a nail came away with the wood, and projecting, gave a touch of danger to an otherwise petty weapon. I heard a step outside, and incontinently flung open the door and found Montgomery within a yard of it.

column2: He meant to lock the outer door! I raised this nailed stick of mine and cut at his face; but he sprang back.
column3: He meant to lock the outer door! I raised this nailed stick of mine and cut at his face; but he sprang back.

column2: I hesitated a moment, then turned and fled, round the corner of the house.
column3: I hesitated a moment, then turned and fled, round the corner of the house.

column2: Prendick, man! I heard his astonished cry, "don't be a silly ass, man!"
column3: Prendick, man! I heard his astonished cry, "don't be a silly ass, man!"

column2: Another minute, thought I, and he would have had me locked in, and as ready as a hospital rabbit for my fate.
column3: Another minute, thought I, and he would have had me locked in, and as ready as a hospital rabbit for my fate.

column2: He emerged behind the corner, for I heard him shout, "Prendick!"
column3: He emerged behind the corner, for I heard him shout, "Prendick!"

column2: Then he began to run after me, shouting things as he ran.
column3: Then he began to run after me, shouting things as he ran.

column2: This time running blindly, I went northeastward in a direction at right angles to my previous expedition.
column3: This time running blindly, I went northeastward in a direction at right angles to my previous expedition.

column2: Once, as I went running headlong up the beach, I glanced over my shoulder and saw his attendant with him. I ran furiously up the slope, over it, then turning eastward along a rocky valley fringed on either side with jungle I ran for perhaps a mile altogether, my chest straining, my heart beating in my ears; and then hearing nothing of Montgomery or his man, and feeling upon the verge of exhaustion, I doubled sharply back towards the beach as I judged, and lay down in the shelter of a canebrake. There I remained for a long time, too fearful to move, and indeed too fearful even to plan a course of action.
column3: Once, as I went running headlong up the beach, I glanced over my shoulder and saw his attendant with him. I ran furiously up the slope, over it, then turning eastward along a rocky valley fringed on either side with jungle I ran for perhaps a mile altogether, my chest straining, my heart beating in my ears; and then hearing nothing of Montgomery or his man, and feeling upon the verge of exhaustion, I doubled sharply back towards the beach as I judged, and lay down in the shelter of a canebrake. There I remained for a long time, too fearful to move, and indeed too fearful even to plan a course of action.

column2: The wild scene about me lay sleeping silently under the sun, and the only sound near me was the thin hum of some small gnats that had discovered me.
column3: The wild scene about me lay sleeping silently under the sun, and the only sound near me was the thin hum of some small gnats that had discovered me.

column2: Presently I became aware of a drowsy breathing sound, the soughing of the sea upon the beach.
column3: Presently I became aware of a drowsy breathing sound, the soughing of the sea upon the beach.

column2: After about an hour I heard Montgomery shouting my name, far away to the north.
column3: After about an hour I heard Montgomery shouting my name, far away to the north.

column2: That set me thinking of my plan of action. As I interpreted it then, this island was inhabited only by these two vivisectors and their animalised victims.
column3: That set me thinking of my plan of action. As I interpreted it then, this island was inhabited only by these two vivisectors and their animalised victims.

column2: Some of these no doubt they could press into their service against me if need arose. I knew both Moreau and Montgomery carried revolvers; and, save for a feeble bar of deal spiked with a small nail, the merest mockery of a mace, I was unarmed.
column3: Some of these no doubt they could press into their service against me if need arose. I knew both Moreau and Montgomery carried revolvers; and, save for a feeble bar of deal spiked with a small nail, the merest mockery of a mace, I was unarmed.

column2: So I lay still there, until I began to think of food and drink; and at that thought the real hopelessness of my position came home to me. I knew no way of getting anything to eat.
column3: So I lay still there, until I began to think of food and drink; and at that thought the real hopelessness of my position came home to me. I knew no way of getting anything to eat.

column2: I was too ignorant of botany to discover any resort of root or fruit that might lie about me; I had no means of trapping the few rabbits upon the island. It grew blanker the more I turned the prospect over.
column3: I was too ignorant of botany to discover any resort of root or fruit that might lie about me; I had no means of trapping the few rabbits upon the island. It grew blanker the more I turned the prospect over.

column2: At last in the desperation of my position, my mind turned to the animal men I had encountered.
column3: At last in the desperation of my position, my mind turned to the animal men I had encountered.

column2: I tried to find some hope in what I remembered of them. In turn I recalled each one I had seen, and tried to draw some augury of assistance from my memory.
column3: I tried to find some hope in what I remembered of them. In turn I recalled each one I had seen, and tried to draw some augury of assistance from my memory.

column2: Then suddenly I heard a staghound bay, and at that realised a new danger. I took little time to think, or they would have caught me then, but snatching up my nailed stick, rushed headlong from my hiding-place towards the sound of the sea.
column3: Then suddenly I heard a staghound bay, and at that realised a new danger. I took little time to think, or they would have caught me then, but snatching up my nailed stick, rushed headlong from my hiding place towards the sound of the sea.

column2: I remember a growth of thorny plants, with spines that stabbed like pen-knives.
column3: I remember a growth of thorny plants, with spines that stabbed like pen knives.

column2: I emerged bleeding and with torn clothes upon the lip of a long creek opening northward. I went straight into the water without a minute's hesitation, wading up the creek, and presently finding myself kneedeep in a little stream. I scrambled out at last on the westward bank, and with my heart beating loudly in my ears, crept into a tangle of ferns to await the issue. I heard the dog (there was only one) draw nearer, and yelp when it came to the thorns.
column3: I emerged bleeding and with torn clothes upon the lip of a long creek opening northward. I went straight into the water without a minute's hesitation, wading up the creek, and presently finding myself kneedeep in a little stream. I scrambled out at last on the westward bank, and with my heart beating loudly in my ears, crept into a tangle of ferns to await the issue. I heard the dog (there was only one) draw nearer, and yelp when it came to the thorns.

column2: Then I heard no more, and presently began to think I had escaped.
column3: Then I heard no more, and presently began to think I had escaped.

column2: The minutes passed; the silence lengthened out, and at last after an hour of security my courage began to return to me. By this time I was no longer very much terrified or very miserable. I had, as it were, passed the limit of terror and despair. I felt now that my life was practically lost, and that persuasion made me capable of daring anything.
column3: The minutes passed; the silence lengthened out, and at last after an hour of security my courage began to return to me. By this time I was no longer very much terrified or very miserable. I had, as it were, passed the limit of terror and despair. I felt now that my life was practically lost, and that persuasion made me capable of daring anything.

column2: I had even a certain wish to encounter Moreau face to face; and as I had waded into the water, I remembered that if I were too hard pressed at least one path of escape from torment still lay open to me,--they could not very well prevent my drowning myself.
column3: I had even a certain wish to encounter Moreau face to face; and as I had waded into the water, I remembered that if I were too hard pressed at least one path of escape from torment still lay open to me,--they could not very well prevent my drowning myself.

column2: I had half a mind to drown myself then; but an odd wish to see the whole adventure out, a queer, impersonal, spectacular interest in myself, restrained me. I stretched my limbs, sore and painful from the pricks of the spiny plants, and stared around me at the trees; and, so suddenly that it seemed to jump out of the green tracery about it, my eyes lit upon a black face watching me.
column3: I had half a mind to drown myself then; but an odd wish to see the whole adventure out, a queer, impersonal, spectacular interest in myself, restrained me. I stretched my limbs, sore and painful from the pricks of the spiny plants, and stared around me at the trees; and, so suddenly that it seemed to jump out of the green tracery about it, my eyes lit upon a black face watching me.

column2: I saw that it was the simian creature who had met the launch upon the beach.
column3: I saw that it was the simian creature who had met the launch upon the beach.

column2: He was clinging to the oblique stem of a palm-tree.
column3: He was clinging to the oblique stem of a palm tree.

column2: I gripped my stick, and stood up facing him. He began chattering.
column3: I gripped my stick, and stood up facing him. He began chattering.

column2: You, you, you, was all I could distinguish at first.
column3: You, you, you, was all I could distinguish at first.

column2: Suddenly he dropped from the tree, and in another moment was holding the fronds apart and staring curiously at me.
column3: Suddenly he dropped from the tree, and in another moment was holding the fronds apart and staring curiously at me.

column2: I did not feel the same repugnance towards this creature which I had experienced in my encounters with the other Beast Men. "You," he said, "in the boat." He was a man, then,--at least as much of a man as Montgomery's attendant,--for he could talk.
column3: I did not feel the same repugnance towards this creature which I had experienced in my encounters with the other Beast Men. "You," he said, "in the boat." He was a man, then,--at least as much of a man as Montgomery's attendant,--for he could talk.

column2: Yes, I said, "I came in the boat.
column3: Yes, I said, "I came in the boat.

column2: From the ship."
column3: From the ship."

column2: Oh! he said, and his bright, restless eyes travelled over me, to my hands, to the stick I carried, to my feet, to the tattered places in my coat, and the cuts and scratches I had received from the thorns. He seemed puzzled at something.
column3: Oh! he said, and his bright, restless eyes travelled over me, to my hands, to the stick I carried, to my feet, to the tattered places in my coat, and the cuts and scratches I had received from the thorns. He seemed puzzled at something.

column2: His eyes came back to my hands. He held his own hand out and counted his digits slowly, "One, two, three, four, five--eigh?"
column3: His eyes came back to my hands. He held his own hand out and counted his digits slowly, "One, two, three, four, five-eigh?"

column2: I did not grasp his meaning then; afterwards I was to find that a great proportion of these Beast People had malformed hands, lacking sometimes even three digits.
column3: I did not grasp his meaning then; afterwards I was to find that a great proportion of these Beast People had malformed hands, lacking sometimes even three digits.

column2: But guessing this was in some way a greeting, I did the same thing by way of reply. He grinned with immense satisfaction.
column3: But guessing this was in some way a greeting, I did the same thing by way of reply. He grinned with immense satisfaction.

column2: Then his swift roving glance went round again; he made a swift movement--and vanished. The fern fronds he had stood between came swishing together.
column3: Then his swift roving glance went round again; he made a swift movement-and vanished. The fern fronds he had stood between came swishing together.

column2: I pushed out of the brake after him, and was astonished to find him swinging cheerfully by one lank arm from a rope of creepers that looped down from the foliage overhead.
column3: I pushed out of the brake after him, and was astonished to find him swinging cheerfully by one lank arm from a rope of creepers that looped down from the foliage overhead.

column2: His back was to me.
column3: His back was to me.

column2: Hullo! said I.
column3: Hullo! said i

column2: He came down with a twisting jump, and stood facing me.
column3: He came down with a twisting jump, and stood facing me.

column2: I say, said I, "where can I get something to eat?"
column3: I say, said I, "where can I get something to eat?"

column2: Eat! he said.
column3: Eat! he said.

column2: Eat Man's food, now. And his eye went back to the swing of ropes.
column3: Eat Man's food, now. And his eye went back to the swing of ropes.

column2: At the huts.
column3: At the huts.

column2: But where are the huts?
column3: But where are the huts?

column2: Oh!
column3: Oh!

column2: I'm new, you know.
column3: I'm new, you know.

column2: At that he swung round, and set off at a quick walk. All his motions were curiously rapid.
column3: At that he swung round, and set off at a quick walk. All his motions were curiously rapid.

column2: Come along, said he.
column3: Come along, said he.

column2: I went with him to see the adventure out.
column3: I went with him to see the adventure out.

column2: I guessed the huts were some rough shelter where he and some more of these Beast People lived. I might perhaps find them friendly, find some handle in their minds to take hold of.
column3: I guessed the huts were some rough shelter where he and some more of these Beast People lived. I might perhaps find them friendly, find some handle in their minds to take hold of.

column2: I did not know how far they had forgotten their human heritage.
column3: I did not know how far they had forgotten their human heritage.

column2: My ape-like companion trotted along by my side, with his hands hanging down and his jaw thrust forward.
column3: My ape like companion trotted along by my side, with his hands hanging down and his jaw thrust forward.

column2: I wondered what memory he might have in him.
column3: I wondered what memory he might have in him.

column2: How long have you been on this island? said I.
column3: How long have you been on this island? said i

column2: How long? he asked; and after having the question repeated, he held up three fingers.
column3: How long? he asked; and after having the question repeated, he held up three fingers.

column2: The creature was little better than an idiot.
column3: The creature was little better than an idiot.

column2: I tried to make out what he meant by that, and it seems I bored him. After another question or two he suddenly left my side and went leaping at some fruit that hung from a tree.
column3: I tried to make out what he meant by that, and it seems I bored him. After another question or two he suddenly left my side and went leaping at some fruit that hung from a tree.

column2: He pulled down a handful of prickly husks and went on eating the contents. I noted this with satisfaction, for here at least was a hint for feeding. I tried him with some other questions, but his chattering, prompt responses were as often as not quite at cross purposes with my question. Some few were appropriate, others quite parrot-like.
column3: He pulled down a handful of prickly husks and went on eating the contents. I noted this with satisfaction, for here at least was a hint for feeding. I tried him with some other questions, but his chattering, prompt responses were as often as not quite at cross purposes with my question. Some few were appropriate, others quite parrot like.

column2: I was so intent upon these peculiarities that I scarcely noticed the path we followed.
column3: I was so intent upon these peculiarities that I scarcely noticed the path we followed.

column2: Presently we came to trees, all charred and brown, and so to a bare place covered with a yellow-white incrustation, across which a drifting smoke, pungent in whiffs to nose and eyes, went drifting.
column3: Presently we came to trees, all charred and brown, and so to a bare place covered with a yellow white incrustation, across which a drifting smoke, pungent in whiffs to nose and eyes, went drifting.

column2: On our right, over a shoulder of bare rock, I saw the level blue of the sea.
column3: On our right, over a shoulder of bare rock, I saw the level blue of the sea.

column2: The path coiled down abruptly into a narrow ravine between two tumbled and knotty masses of blackish scoriae. Into this we plunged.
column3: The path coiled down abruptly into a narrow ravine between two tumbled and knotty masses of blackish scoriae. Into this we plunged.

column2: It was extremely dark, this passage, after the blinding sunlight reflected from the sulphurous ground.
column3: It was extremely dark, this passage, after the blinding sunlight reflected from the sulphurous ground.

column2: Its walls grew steep, and approached each other.
column3: Its walls grew steep, and approached each other.

column2: Blotches of green and crimson drifted across my eyes. My conductor stopped suddenly.
column3: Blotches of green and crimson drifted across my eyes. My conductor stopped suddenly.

column2: Home! said he, and I stood in a floor of a chasm that was at first absolutely dark to me. I heard some strange noises, and thrust the knuckles of my left hand into my eyes.
column3: Home! said he, and I stood in a floor of a chasm that was at first absolutely dark to me. I heard some strange noises, and thrust the knuckles of my left hand into my eyes.

column2: I became aware of a disagreeable odor, like that of a monkey's cage ill-cleaned.
column3: I became aware of a disagreeable odor, like that of a monkey's cage ill cleaned.

column2: Beyond, the rock opened again upon a gradual slope of sunlit greenery, and on either hand the light smote down through narrow ways into the central gloom.
column3: Beyond, the rock opened again upon a gradual slope of sunlit greenery, and on either hand the light smote down through narrow ways into the central gloom.
